------------------------------------------

The movie's plot is set during 1920s in post-World War I Serbia. Rebuilding after a gruelling armed conflict in which it lost a sizable part of its young male population, the nation is struggling to recover demographically. The situation is especially visible in certain rural parts where this shortage of men threatens to extinguish life completely.

Two sisters, Ognjenka (Sonja KolaÃƒâ€žÃ‚ï¿½ariÃƒâ€žÃ¢â‚¬Â¡) and Mala Boginja (Katarina RadivojeviÃƒâ€žÃ¢â‚¬Â¡) from a fictional Pokrp village that has no males of marrying age set off for the city in search of good men to bring home.

some comments by the critics:

-"a demented Serbian fantasy"

-"postmodern cheerful fairytale for adults"

-"a Serbian version of 'AmÃƒÆ’Ã‚Â©lie', if you think 'AmÃƒÆ’Ã‚Â©lie' is a movie about hot ladies with prominent facial features interacting with a series of expensive digital effects"

-"you really must see it to understand the depths of its batshit craziness"

-"a postmodern allegorical tale" which "succeeds in poking fun at various Serbian national myths and symbols with its strong, lusty, independent women, eager-to-fight men and sacrilegious shenanigans in a hearse and among tombstones"

-"a Grimm's fairy tale come to life, a world where magic exists but is also accompanied by darkness, death, sex and more"

-"a fairy tale filled with dark jokes, estrogen, sex, and explosions"

-"beyond Gilliam with a profoundly Eastern European sensibility and a fascinating approach to the idea of the feminine"

-"maturity in stylistic composition of a comedy that contains patterns of quite a few genres - from melodrama to fantasy"

-"an extraordinary moment for new Serbian film"

-"an example of Serbian megalomania"
